body:
Good catches, @kcooney !

`setParent()`
The state/argument check is currently not violated within the code base, meaning all tests still run when the check is applied.

`removeFromHierarchy()`
The proposed change makes the behaviour more consistent with the implementation of `removeChild()` -- that already calls `child.setParent(null)`

Addressed the two issues in https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/commit/0da282dd71de748012f9be7c9fba549f924dc37c


Caveat: there is still a way to reset the parent of an `AbstractTestDescriptor`. First set it to `null`, then assign the new parent instance. See 
https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/blob/0da282dd71de748012f9be7c9fba549f924dc37c/platform-tests/src/test/java/org/junit/platform/engine/support/descriptor/AbstractTestDescriptorTests.java#L87-L93

Do we need to prevent this too? Or wrap it in a `resetParentTo()` method?

What if an engine actually wants to change its parent-child relationships during discovery, e.g. to "compress" its tree or to group things? IMHO we should allow changing a child's parent. Therefore, I think we should not add any checks to `setParent()` but I'm fine with the proposed modification of `removeFromHierachy()`.
As the new check does not prevent the parent change anyway (see two step test case above) I'm fine with reverting that _fix_.

@marcphilipp good point. You could replace`removeFromHierarchy()` with `removeFromParent()` to allow re-parenting while keeping the tree consistent. I looked at the callers, and none of them need to remove the children from the node.

@sormuras you are right that the fact that `setParent()` exists makes it possible to make inconsistent hierarchies. The only way to avoid that would be to make `TestDescriptor` an abstract class instead of an interface, making `setParent()` package-scope, and making `addChild()` and  `removeChild()` final. If it wasn't so late in the project, I would suggest doing that anyway, since everyone extends from `AbstratTestDescrptor` anyway.

Please keep in mind that TestDescriptors are an API used by test engine authors, not test authors. So, while the flexibility of `TestDescriptor` being an interface introduces the potential of inconsistencies, I expect test engine authors to (a) know what they're doing and (b) thoroughly test their code.

I still think it's good to protect against accidental misuse where possible. The reason why I suggested that `setParent()` should check that there isn't already a parent is because `addChild()` currently allows you to accidentally add a child to two parents, again leading to inconsistencies. Forcing the caller to call `setParenr(null)` to reparent a node at least means that the caller is making their intent clear.

If you want to allow people to compress the tree, replace `removeFromHierarchy()` with `removeFromParent()`. Either way, we should document that `setParent()` should be used with care, and have the JavaDoc reference the preferred methods.

@kcooney, we're right in the middle of the GA release...

Would you mind opening a new issue so that we can revisit this post 5.0 GA?
@sbrannen all the context is in this issue so I will just reopen it and you can target it for another release.
